title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Think on God, Dryfesdale," said George Douglas, "and leave theutterance of those horrors--Repent, if thou canst--if not, at leastbe silent.--Seyton, aid me to support this dying wretch, that he maycompose himself to better thoughts, if it be possible."

title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Ay, and Dryfesdale would that he had been dead," answered the woundedman, "rather than that his ears had heard the words of the only Douglasthat ever was false--but yet it is better as it is.

title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Have they not disarmed thee, Dryfesdale?" she said, on seeing himenter, accoutred, as usual, with sword and dagger.

title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Peradventure we shall learn something concerningthe nostrum she hath ventured, contrary to law and the rules of art, toadhibit to these ladies, through the medium of the steward Dryfesdale."

title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "What has chanced, Dryfesdale, that thou lookest thus?" saidhis mistress--"Have there been evil tidings of my son, or of mygrandchildren?"

title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: It opened at her command, and the steward Dryfesdaleentered, and stood before her with a gloomy and perturbed expression onhis brow.

title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "It is I," replied the harsh and yet slow voice of the stewardDryfesdale.

title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Thou hast the name of a good soldier, Dryfesdale, take allprecautions.--Sacred Heaven! that I should be thus openly insulted!"

title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Thou liest, Dryfesdale," said the Lady, "and wouldst throw the blame onthy master's house, to save the worthless life of a gipsy boy."

title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Madam," said old Dryfesdale the steward, "this much do I say for thissilly page, that he could not be accessary to unlocking the doors, sinceI myself this night bolted him out of the castle.

title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "Make no alarm here," retorted the impenetrable Dryfesdale, "but keepthy sinful oaths and silly threats for those that regard them--I do mineoffice, and carry the keys to the seneschal.--Adieu, my young master!the cool night air will advantage your hot blood."

title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: That little voyage was speedily accomplished, and the page wasgreeted at the landing-place by the severe and caustic welcome of oldDryfesdale.

title: The Abbot
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: He sought to make his parting reverence tothe Queen and her ladies, but old Dryfesdale hurried him to the boat.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: But before Irving left Glasgow, news came to me (from Irving I believe) that Frank, struck quite miserable and lame of heart and nerves by dyspepsia and dispiritment, was home again, or on his way home to Dryfesdale, there to lie useless, Irving rec- omraendiDg me to do for him what kindness I could, and not remember  that he used to disbelieve and be ignorantly cruel in my own dyspeptic tribulations.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: The mother, Mary Gillespie (she had relations at Dryfesdale) was left with her children, and had not always meal to make them porridge.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: ■ The Dryfe rises in the northern end of Hutton parish, andruns a course directly south about eleven miles; passingthroughthe parish of Dryfesdale for about three miles on the N.W.part, it empties itself into the Annan in a direct line betweenthe market town of Loekerby and the royal burgh of Lochmaben.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
